thread.title: Chesterfield mayor, council members slam proposed sales tax hike
thread.title_full: Chesterfield mayor, council members slam proposed sales tax hike

author: Mary Shapiro Special to the Post-Dispatch
title: Chesterfield mayor, council members slam proposed sales tax hike
text:
Chesterfield mayor, council members slam proposed sales tax hike By Mary Shapiro Special to the Post-Dispatch 19 hrs ago ( … ) 
CHESTERFIELD • Mayor Bob Nation and some City Council members protested on Monday that their city will be “a $5 million a year net loser” if St. Louis County voters approve a 0.5 percent sales tax that's on the April 4 ballot. 
Voters will be asked to approve the sales tax increase, which is expected to generate $80 million a year for law enforcement upgrades for the county and its municipalities. 
Plans are for the tax to generate $46 million a year to enable the county police to hire additional officers, increase training and add technology such as body and dash cameras. 
The remainder of the revenue, about $34 million, would be divided among the 57 municipal police agencies in the county, based on population. 
The municipalities would be given the latitude to spend the money as needed, with the stipulation that it be directed solely toward “public safety.” 
Nation said that, while the tax proposal would provide the city with almost $2.4 million in annual revenue, the tax would generate about $7.4 million per year in the city. 
”I extremely and fully support Chesterfield, St. Louis County and other police and law enforcement, in general,” Nation said. 
“But public safety is a broad term and could apply to many things – the ballot wording is misleading," he added. "An extra $7.4 million a year will be extracted from our shoppers and taxpayers. I’m skeptical this tax increase countywide would be a good thing.” 
Nation also said most of the counties in Missouri with such a law enforcement sales taxes are rural and, unlike urban and suburban counties, don’t have a large enough tax base to independently support law enforcement. 
Councilwoman Barb McGuinness said that passage of the new tax “will be worse for us than the county pool tax." 
"Has the county demonstrated a need for this money?” she asked. 
Nation said the new tax “would push our city to the brink.” 
He said St. Louis County’s population “has been stagnant for decades” and that many people have been moving to St. Charles, Jefferson, Warren and other outlying counties due to lower costs of living. 
“If voters add this tax, it will be another reason for people to flee St. Louis County and will create a less than ideal economic environment,” Nation said. 
He said the city had favored previous unsuccessful proposals, such as one that would have increased the sales tax by 0.5 percent only in the unincorporated county but which would have generated only $16 million more annually for the county. 
“I’ve heard a number of mayors say they don’t have a need to spend more on law enforcement and that they’d use this money for something else,” Nation said. “This tax would just grow government, make any corrupt government bigger and unduly tax the taxpayers.” 
Councilman Tom DeCampi said he felt the current sales tax proposal “feels like tax-and-spend redistribution under the guise of public safety.” 
He called the proposed use of funding by the county for more officer training and more body and dashboard cameras “code that police are bad and can’t be trusted.” 
“I feel it’s a privacy issue — also, bad cops can turn a camera off,” he said. 
“If a city wants these cameras, it can purchase them. We don’t need them in Chesterfield," DeCampi said. "To me, this is something taken out of the playbook of former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder, which fomented a lot of anti-police rhetoric.” Tags
